abstract.t: The HyperText Transfer Protocol (HTTP) has been widely used by the World Wide Web (WWW) since 1990. This specification attempts to define how to parse HTTP requests and responses in a way that is compatible with user-agents (UAs) and servers at the time of writing.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: Ever since HTTP's conception, there have never been any standards regarding its parsing in the real world. tried to improve this situation with a section (19.3) entited "Tolerant Applications", providing advice about parsing requests and responses. However, it did not go into specific details that are needed for interoperability with current (non-conformant) servers. The lack of any current specification defining such specifics makes it hard for any new UA to be created without first spending large amounts of time reverse engineering what is in cases purely bizzare behaviour, which unless you know about beforehand, you may not write enough test cases to find some of the oddest behaviour.

This specification aims to help the above mentioned problem by documenting the behaviour of UAs at the time of writing. As with any data format without specified error handling, this behaviour is likely to change over time.

section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in .

section.title: Conformance Requirements
section.t: This specification is defined in terms of the US-ASCII character set, as defined in .

The conformance requirements of this specification are phrased as algorithms and may be implemented in any manner, so long as the end result is equivalent (in particular, the algorithms defined in this specification are intended to be easy to follow, and not intended to be performant).

User agents may impose implementation-specific limits on otherwise unconstrained inputs, e.g., to prevent denial of service attacks, to guard against running out of memory, or to work around platform-specific limitations.

section.title: Parsing
section.t: Implementations of this specification MUST implement the below algorithms.

section.title: Collect Bytes That Are In The Group
section.t: When an algorithm requires the parser to "collect bytes", the following algorithm MUST be run, with "bytes" being the set of bytes that can be collected:

list.t: Let "input" and "position" be the same variables as those of the same name in the algorithm that invoked these steps.
While "position" doesn't point past the end of "input" and the byte at position is one of the "bytes", append that byte to the end of "result" and advance "position" to the next byte in "input".

section.title: Collect Bytes That Aren't In The Group
section.t: When an algorithm requires the parser to "collect bytes that aren't", the following algorithm MUST be run, with "bytes" being the set of bytes that cannot be collected:

list.t: Let "input" and "position" be the same variables as those of the same name in the algorithm that invoked these steps.
While "position" doesn't point past the end of "input" and the byte at position is not one of the "bytes", append that byte to the end of "result" and advance "position" to the next byte in "input".

section.title: Skip Inline Whitespace
section.t: When an algorithm requires the parser to "skip inline whitespace", the parser MUST collect bytes that are either 0x09 (US-ASCII horizontal tab) or 0x20 (US-ASCII space).

section.title: Is Linear Whitespace
section.t: When an algorithm requires the parser to see if the following byte "is linear whitespace", the following algorithm MUST be run:

list.t: Let "input" and "position" be the same variables as those of the same name in the algorithm that invoked these steps.
If "position" points to 0x09 (US-ASCII horizontal tab), then return true, otherwise proceed to the next step.
If "position" points to 0x20 (US-ASCII space), then return true, otherwise proceed to the next step.
If "position" points to 0x0D (US-ASCII character return), then return true, otherwise proceed to the next step.
If "position" points to 0x0A (US-ASCII line feed), and is followed by either 0x09 (US-ASCII horizontal tab) or 0x20 (US-ASCII space), then return true, otherwise proceed to the next step.
The next byte is not linear whitespace. Return false.

section.title: Parse Linear Whitespace
section.t: When an algorithm requires the parser to "parse linear whitespace", the following algorithm MUST be run:

list.t: Let "input", "position", and "value" be the same variables as those of the same name in the algorithm that invoked these steps.
If the following byte is linear whitespace then advance "position" to the next byte in "input" before repeating this step.
Append a single 0x20 (US-ASCII space) byte to the end of "value".

appendix.title: Further Suggestions
appendix.t: While the scope of this specification is only parsing of HTTP requests and responses, there are several other things that I am aware of that should be pointed out to anyone implementing :

list.t: The Content-Location header SHOULD be ignored. This is due to multiple versions of Microsoft Internet Information Services (IIS) sending incorrect Content-Location headers. Implementing this as required by will break a significant number of websites.

The Content-Type SHOULD NOT on its own be trusted. Content-Type sniffing as defined in SHOULD be used to determine the true type of the resource. This is due to a large number of websites sending incorrect Content-Type headers, often because the maintainer of the website cannot change the header, or because the file extension/MIME type database is outdated.
